Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

n/a... always spoke with JDRS.
Matto Mildenberg
I never interacted with a TA.
I preferred simply going to the professor.
NA. I did not interact with the TAs much at all. Please see below.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  Matto.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  Matto was great and very helpful.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  I never interacted very closely with either TA.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  Only talked to Matto a couple times, but he was very helpful + a nice guy.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  Sometimes I felt that he is not very careful in grading.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  Very helpful and willing to help
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  Matto
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  matto
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  He was great.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  Met once in office hours - gave a great explanation of the material.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  N/A
Instructor: Yitian Huang  Yitian Huang
Instructor: Yitian Huang  Yitian offered fantastic homework help. He was willing to explain things over and over, or in as many different ways as he could, until I understood.
Instructor: Yitian Huang  I didn't go to the teaching assistants until the end, but they were helpful when I did.
Instructor: Yitian Huang  Yitian Huang
Instructor: Yitian Huang  Yitian Huang

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This course was fantastic and the professor was extremely knowledgable, friendly, and accessible to students. Thank you for a wonderful and very applicable educational experience!
This is an excellent class and I highly recommend it and Professor Reuning-Scherer to all FES students. However, it is most certainly not an easy class.

With regard to questions 12& 13, I felt that the course material was confusing when presented in class. The pace was very fast and I often had to spend a lot of time outside class teaching myself material that we had covered. That said, the times I met with JRS in person to receive extra help, his instruction was extraordinarily clear and helpful. I'm not sure why the difference between the two media - in class vs. one-on-one - but it was frustrating that I had trouble keeping up in class.

Question 4 - - This course went way too fast; the instructor even spoke so fast I could barely understand him at times. I would recommend cutting the amount of introductory material down in order to go over concepts more clearly and slowly.
Statistics is the pits,but JRS makes it sweet.
this was a great class!!

Reuning-Scherer's is a great guy. His lectures are one of a kind. Constantly cracking jokes + amazingly upbeat all of the time. The amount of energy he brings to class every day is truly amazing.All that being said, I don't really learn a lot from getting lectured in statistics. I really think stats is something you learn by doing, and the homework assignments, take-home mid-terms, and group project were all aided my learning much more than the class time itself. I can't really knock Reuning-Scherer because I can't think of a better way to teach the class (large stats classes just aren't very useful in my opinion). Class is very entertaining, just don't know how useful it is. I started to skip class frequently towards the end of the semester and just devote that work to the homeworks + projects. Found it to be a more productive use of my time.Reuning-Scherer is extremely helpful + nice outside of class. I was really impressed with how available he was during the group projects...he spent hours hanging out in CSSSI just helping all of us out.
I felt that we moved very quickly through the material. It was a good introduction to statistics, but I am not sure that I could apply the knowledge that I learned.
Jonathan is awesome. He makes a daunting topic fun. My only negative feedback is about statistics itself... just not a topic I consider fun. But Jonathan makes lemonade from lemons!
Great support from TA Yitian
Jonathan was a very skilled instructor - the content of the class was organized and planned very thoroughly. The HW assignments and final project provided good practice for the subject material.
The professor in this course is great, with a good sense of humor, and a clear demonstration of terms.
Professor Reuning-Sherer is fantastic. I really appreciated the take home exams and final project; it make the class far more accessible to someone who isn't math savvy.
Great class as introduction to Statistics.
JDRS is a great professor, it's not his fault I was confused most of the time. It's a hard subject to teach to a group of clueless students.
n/a
Professor Reuning-Scherer was wonderful! I can't imagine any other professor making statistics as enjoyable as he did. I looked forward to coming to class each day. Thank you!
Jonathan is an amazing professor! I will definitely take more courses with him.
Please see below.

Some material was presented too slowly (earlier on in the class) but other areas were to quick (probability, GLM, etc...). Would be better if more time were spent reviewing probability and modeling (multiple linear regression, GLM, etc...) since that is more likely what we will be using the course knowledge for. Also, less time on the mathematical underpinnings of the models and more time on how they work and actually using them.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The course material was designed to be interesting, relevant and clear and the professor is truly talented at teaching.
Dr. Reuning-Scherer is a capable and engaging professor.
The professor is incredibly engaging and a fun teacher. His teaching style is energetic and always interesting.
Professor Reuning-Scherer's teaching style. He is interactive and makes what could be a very boring topic very interesting.
Office hours and homework review sessions with JRS were very helpful.
Homeworks were quite helpful, and the second half of the course seemed really applicable to a lot of environmental science.
JRS
The instructor was full of energy and tried to make a difficult subject fun and easy to learn.

The professor was absolutely outstanding and truly cared about the subject matter and teaching it to his students. This course really helped me understand many of the studies and projects I have researched.

I gained a clearer understanding of statistical analysis through this course. Similar to other courses, I wanted to understand regression analysis from the standpoint of policy and I believe I got there because of this class.
Lectures, Examples, assignments and office hours
Professor. Very funny. Very willing to help outside of class (which is critical in stats).
Professor Reuning Scherer!
Professor Reuning-Scherer is a lovely person who clearly cares very much about teaching. I learned a ton.
Jonathan is an enthusiastic teacher who not only wants to teach, but to learn from his students about how he can be a better teacher.
Professor's availability outside of lecture

Jonathan is an excellent instructor. He makes statistics fun, a difficult task indeed. He is approachable and willing to answer questions in person, via email, or via phone/ Skype. He uses examples that make statistics come to life. The assignments provide excellent hands-on practice with statistics, as did the final project. I now feel like I have a much better grasp on the practical use of statistics than after having taken stats in my undergrad.
The last month of the course where you get to see how the concepts are applied. Also I liked the real world examples and data sets that were used throughout the course.
Make stats not that boring.
The professor's sense of humor and the final project.
Homeworks and activities in class.
JDRS's lectures! His examples and terrible (sorry) jokes made the class more interesting.
Ability to work together on homeworks and final project.
Problem sets really helped clarify the material. Jonathan was very accessible, responsive and engaging (funny) in class - great personality.
Lecture was fun, and the weekly problem sets really allowed me the opportunity to synthesize the material from lecture.
Good survey of statistical concepts. Instructor is accessible.
The professor's jokes were amazing.
The teacher is very generous and willing to help with everything.
The teacher!
the problem sets

Professor Reuning-Scherer is one of the most talented lecturers I have ever had. He does an exceptional job of making his lectures interesting and relevant for FES students. I was very impressed by his ability to make statistics come to life and hold our attention even in the midst of learning dense material. He is also very approachable and patient in answering questions.
Final project
Learning how to use Multiple Linear Regression and GLM.
The pedagogy and style of the instructor made the subject quite interesting. The course helped me better understand certain concepts in other subjects such as Economics and Energy Systems Analysis

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I thought it was very well done and have no suggestions for improvement. Though I wouldn't have minded using SPSS or R instead of Minitab, as they seem to be more common in many professional settings.

The use of MINITAB throughout the semester is testimony that we now have programs that can do math for us. However, I think it would be helpful if we were required to do calculations either by hand or with a graphing calculator; actually going through the process is, for me, a good means of learning the significance of each step of the equations.
I wish we would've had readings to supplement class. The class moved too quickly to be able to absorb everything and the class notes didn't always make sense in review.
None
The pace. Too fast!

I found it really frustrating that the professor blasted through the math behind all the statistics so fast that there was no way we could understand or follow. It was kind of comical. What resulted was that I didn't understand the math behind the concepts, and I almost think the professor designed it so I couldn't. But the math isn't hard - - it's mostly just algebra - - so I wish he had either slowed down enough to teach it to us for real or just skipped it entirely.
It would be nice to sometimes relate things to the bigger picture more often so I would have known how different things related to one another.
The notes provided to the class are great, but they are a little dense for moving through during a class period. I got the most out of working through problems in class.

For students who have no math background, it would be very helpful to have guidance above and beyond what the TAs are assigned to provide help for. I struggled a lot with the content and would have benefited from guidance and support, or referrals to someone who could help me.
N/A
Didn't find lectures very useful but I think this relates more to the subject (stats) than the professor. Can't think of a better way to run lectures.
It would have been helpful to have 1 stats book assigned to refer to.
not sure

The PDF lecture notes were sometimes difficult to follow, as JDRS moves around them quickly. But I did appreciate having half a semester's notes in advance. A shorter text would have been nice, as the textbook was so long it was too time-consuming to read, but it would have been nice to have had some other type of shorter text summary to read for further comprehension. The textbook seemed to have a lot of extraneous information that was not covered in the class, and didn't focus enough on the key concepts we learned.The second midterm needs to be earlier, because it ended up falling in the last week of class when we all had final exams, final projects, and final papers due, but we also had a final stats project, so we essentially ended up with two final stats projects (the project and the midterm) to add to all of our other work in the last two weeks of the term, which was too much of a workload. It would have been better had this second midterm been a week or two earlier, and we only had the final project to contend with during the final rush of the term.

Perhaps a couple example problems immediately following each class with answers and explanations, for additional practice - in addition to the graded HW.Aside from class material -- 1130-1245 is not the time for a class! There are so many activities going on during lunch that it conflicts with the class.

I think that the probability section of the course should be slowed down. Also it seemed that the problem sets in this section didn't reflect what we had gone over during class so I was lost when trying to do the homework.
The grading criteria of TA.
It makes a little too fast. I really enjoyed the class where we worked out the regression together with our laptops. I think doing this more often in the class would be useful.
Too much information in just 2 classes per week
I think the project should be assigned halfway through the semester, so people don't leave it till the end and then make a mad dash for the airport (like I did)!
Lectures - professor talks really fast. The material isn't that enaging, so it helps to use the clickers for quizzes or integrate practice problems into the lecture session to facilitate learning.
everything is great
Once-weekly homework assignments were only moderately helpful. Perhaps weekly group TA sessions and/or more and shorter HW assignments would have been helpful.
Honestly, I didn't need a textbook for the course. I bought one at the beginning as per the advice of the professor, but the notes were far more useful than the textbook.
the pace of the lectures. maybe it should be broken down on two semester so topics can be explained more in depth

I felt that the material was covered too quickly in this course. Professor Reuning-Scherer had helpful, interactive review sessions before the midterm and final but I would have benefited from more regular overviews of what we had already learned and how it related to new material. Because statistics is a field in which more complicated techniques build upon foundations, it would have definitely helped my learning to have more regular reviews of where we had been and where we were going with the material.

The last part of the course seemed a bit rushed. I think it would be nice to have an outline of each analysis and the steps (sort of a summary of the notes, including the details in the flow chart at the end).
See question 15
This course should be taught over two semesters, and still offered for three credits over the two semesters so that students can really learn the material.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
N/A
There was no lab section .

I found the review sessions and extra time outside class to be very valuable and a good use of my time. If the lecture sessions could be more like those sessions I think it would be an outstanding course.
The help sessions were very helpful for the p sets and understanding general concepts.
Helpful tutorials.
Awesome.
Discussion sections w/ Reuning-Scherer were very helpful.
conceptual work in class, practical work on minitab. Again, JDRS is awesome.
I only attended a lab section once or twice. It was primarily a question and answer period, and so I didn't find it particularly helpful.
N/A
n/a
Better integration of class and TAs would have been helpful. TAs are there to answer specific questions, but general review sessions and tutorials were missing.
There were no discussion/lab sections
they were good.
There were no discussion sections. Professor Reuning-Scherer did have weekly office hours which I wished I had attended regularly rather than on just a few occasions!
Office hours should be extended.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: No weaknesses noted. He was very helpful in handling my unique class situation.
no interaction with TAs.
Matto was a good TA. I didn't interact with him too much, but he seems like he knows his stuff, and he seemed helpful. I appreciated how he returned our marked assignments to us so quickly.
There were one or two times where we worked on problems in class - the TAs should have been present then to assist the students.
I barely went to see the TAs but when I did they were helpful
they were great
I only met with the teaching assistant once. He was unfamiliar with Minitab, which was the reason I went to see him. He also was not sure what the right answers were of the homework assignment.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  Matto is a solid TA. Didn't talk to him too many times. Spent more time going directly to Reuning-Scherer.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  Two TAs should be more consistent with their grading criteria.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  We only communicated over email, but he was thorough and helpful.

Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  I only went to Matto once at the beginning of the semester. I unfortunately found his explanations more confusing than helpful and I therefore went to Professor Reuning-Scherer with questions instead.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  Very detailed comments, which was very constructive.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  The TA was quite patient and helpful.
Instructor: Matto Mildenberger  The teaching assistant was great. He took his time, but there are a lot of students in this course. There should be more teaching assistants.
Instructor: Yitian Huang  Yitian was very helpful! I really enjoyed working with him and he provided clear examples to help us understand material.
Instructor: Yitian Huang  both yitan and matto knew the topic inside out but grading was a tad inconsitent

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I believe that Stats relates to any academic program at all; I am an ecology/evolutionary biology major and believe that my overall understanding of research produced by others or my own plans for research will be greatly enhanced by this course.
This course is not actually a requirement for my graduation.
Really important class for me since I do ecological research. I use statistics in everything I do and this class gave me a good basic understanding.

Important because I have only a little bit of stats training prior to this class. It is a pre-requisite for upper level classes I am interested in, but even if it wasn't I would have taken it. I am MESc so this course isnot required.
Understanding statistical tools and learning to interpret statistical results is essential for any field. This class fits very well with my overall program.
Statistics is required in a variety of subjects and work places. I have no doubt that I will use the statistics learned in this class for both school and work-related projects in the future.
I can no look at statistical analysis of a policy and understand what the policy analyst is saying. That is extremely helpful for my focus on policy.

The class covers interesting things to be applied in my research and in my career. As forester manager, notions of probability, hypothesis testing, sampling design, confidence intervals and linear and non linear regression are critical to interpret scientific knowledge and link with policy and decision-makers.
Everyone should know basic stats.

I will be better able to review scientific papers and extract information, but I am not sure how well I could perform research and analyze the data, but I guess that is the purpose of advance statistics courses. So it fit into my "plan" well.

Although I had taken Biostat class during my undergraduate, it was long time ago. This course will be very helpful for my Masters' Project. I am planning to take additional statistics courses on coming semesters so this will serve me as the foundation to those courses.
I had no statistics experience, so this was a great introduction.
Stats is useful to know for just about anything in life IMO.

I think Stats is a helpful base to have for any university program, as it makes it easier to understand academic studies/ articles. This was a very practical course that gave hands-on practice using statistics, which will particularly be helpful for anyone pursuing a thesis-based masters. It is also helpful to better understand statistics published in popular media.
Stats is the foundation for everything.

It was helpful for understanding basic stats that I will apply to my summer research. However I will probably have to spend a lot more time learning other types of stats in order to analyze all my research data.
I feel like it was somewhat relevant but I can't see myself pursuing projects that involve statistics.
This class will help me have better abilities to read scientific papers and interpret data sets that require to have overall statistical analyses.

I had stats in undergrad, but had been quite a while. I appreciated the Stats Universe diagram to lay out where intro stats falls within the broader statistical tools and which academic fields commonly use which method.
will use statistical analysis in my research
Statistics is simply good information/knowledge to have. I'm glad to now understand basic statistical concepts and practices.
Essential for understanding forest measurements and sampling techniques.
Statistics is the lingua-franca of science; to understand it is to possess the ability to communicate science.
Statistics is important for quantifying uncertainty.
I am a masters in environmental science student, and I would say this course is very important to designing research.

I am interested in environmental communication and understanding statistics is critical for understanding public opinion polls of how and why people react to different messaging approaches the way that they do.
It doesn't.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn the material, and it also counted towards my major in EEB.
I wanted to brush up on my maths.
This course was recommended as a foundations course.
Relevant to my field of interest.
To learn about stats! I understand how statistics are used in the scientific literature so this exposed me to the underlying theory and methodology.
To learn how to use different statistical tools and to learn how to interpret statistical figures provided in research papers.
Interest - - I want to be able to understand statistics in scientific papers and newspaper articles and everything in between.
I needed to take a statistics course for my application to the five year program.
had to
I wanted a solid understanding of statistics.
To learn a helpful methodological tool
I did take this class to gain a background in sampling design, data analysis and data interpretation for my research and my future career.
Everyone should know stats.
Because it was a foundations course, and because I have never taken statistics before so felt that my skills were lacking
I need statistics for research and further studies. This course has prepared me for additional statistics courses.
Foundations requirement and stats is a weakness for me.

I wanted a refresher of statistics as it had been a while since I took it in my undergrad. I also wanted to brush up on my quantitative skills. I thought Jonathan seemed like a great instructor and I thought it was a good opportunity to learn statistics from an engaging prof.
Stats is the foundation for everything, and I had never taken a full course.
To analyze my data from my summer research.
I thought I needed a better understanding of the math applications of environmental management.
Because I needed to reinforce my statistics knowledge
I thought it would be useful to have some mathematics background.
Refresh prior knowledge, fulfill Foundation requirement, and see whether I wanted to take additional stats courses.
to get a good foundation in statistics
Useful and required.
See answer above.
See above.
to refresh some statistics courses that i had not review since highschool
Please see above. A basic understanding of statistics is, in my opinion, relevant to almost any field of study and professional endeavor.
To get a refresher on statistical analysis and an introduction to basic statistical software.
It was a foundations course and a necessary skill set.
Fill a requirement

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, absolutely.
It was helpful.
Yes! I feel much more comfortable with statistics now.
Yes.
I don't feel as confident with the probability theory as I was hoping. And the biggest question in my mind is still just figuring out which tests to use for different questions.
Yes
Yes.
Yes, it really helped me understand what was going on in most of the scientific papers I read for other classes.
yes
Yes.

Yes, but I wish I could have just focused more on learning rather than submitting the homework sets. Because I do not have a strong math background, I would have loved to learn the concepts and internalize the statistical procedures. Sometimes the fast nature of the course lent itself to 'repeating' what was taught in class without understanding the underlying concepts well. I would have personally done better with less homework assignments and more time to focus on doing readings and understanding the concepts.
As a prerequisite to more developed analysis, yes!
Yes.
Yes
Yes, given the time of 4 months, I learned a lot.
Yes, I think I have a good understanding of basic statistics now.
they exceeded expectations.
Yes
Yes - I am more familiar with basic stats.
For the most part.
Yes!
Somewhat; I still do not feel like I can takle statistical analysis without major handholding from the professor.
Yes.

This course did not fit my personal learning style. I found it really difficult to absorb the material in lecture format. Occasionally we would work out a problem with classmates in class; this was quite constructive, and should be done more often.
absolutely
yes
Yes, abosolutely.
Yes.
Absolutely!
Yes.

While I can see the statistical structures as they apply to science and research design, I wish that the course had given me enough theory, etc to be able to see how statistics applies to many other situations.
i hope to have a better command of some of the more complex methods

I am honestly disappointed that I do not feel like I have a better grasp of statistics after taking this course. This is partly my own fault since I definitely would have gotten more out of this course had I kept up with the reading. Professor Reuning-Scherer allowed us flexibility in choosing what text to buy but it would have been very useful to have chapters identified that would be relevant for each week's material. Also, as said above, I felt like there was a bit too much material covered a bit too quickly in this course and I would have benefited from more regular reviews of previous material.
Yes, the chart at the end was helpful for deciding which statistics course to take next.
Yes.
Yes
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We used our different strengths and were able to learn from one another while dividing up work equally.
There was no group work I participated in.
I like group work because it help reiterate points. However, it is difficult to coordinate for longer term projects.

Depended on the group - the first group I was in moved too quickly, so I had trouble keeping up. The other group moved at the right pace but none of us is particularly stats-minded so we often convinced ourselves of things that weren't right.

By working in a group to do the statistics project, I was able to understand statistical methods more clearly. Working in a group also helped to share and divide the workload. This also provided avenue to work in collaboration with each other.
Great to be able to do our final project as a group.
Very helpful as it brought together the total knowledge learnedin the class into one project.
Everybody came from different education so working in group helps to complete each other and catch up some thing I do not understand in the class.
n/a
Great collaboration - workload slightly unequal, but that is inevitable

There is a final project as part of this course, which can be done as a group project. This was a nice way to end off the course, as it enabled us to apply what we'd learned to a real-world situation.

The group work I did in this class was the most enjoyable group work I have ever experienced. I think this is 1) because we were able to choose our own groups 2) because we were able to choose our own projects and 3) because we worked independently (other than for a client) which is how most of my other group work has been.
Feedback and help from peers.
I learned that I should have started my project earlier! And possibly worked on my own!
n/a
I wish mygroup members had been a little more serious about the timeframe for submission.
advantage was that we were able to learn from each other mistakes.disadvantage was that because of different schedules, we were almost late for the final project
Being able to collaborate on the homework assignments and working in groups on the final projects was incredibly helpful. I learned a great deal from my peers in this course.
Working in a group helped me with my homework. I could finish it faster and verify my concepts.
It was a great learning experience.
It's group work. There are always somepeople that do more work, and some people that do less.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Go to lecture! Always! It is very helpful and entertaining.
Go to the review sessions and read the slides prior to arriving.
Take it! It is difficult and you may regret it if you don't work hard or are overly concerned about grades, but it is well worth it.

Work in a group that moves at the right pace, but also includes someone for whom stats is familiar and easy to understand to make sure you are approaching questions correctly. Go to the extra sessions!

I would highly encourage students with very little statistics background to take this class. The examples in the class are drawn from politics to environment and I believe that this class will allow someone with no statistical knowledge to develop the knowledge gradually.
Get through the first half - - it'll get easier and better and more applicable.
Pay attention in class and if you don't understand something, ask sooner rather than later because concepts are often build upon.
Don't start the p set the day before it is due!
work hard and get excited by the content!
I highly recommend students to take this class, however it depends on everyone's previous background in statistics.
Use Reuning-Scherer outside of class. He's a great resource + very nice guy. Start on HW early so you can ask him for help.
This course is essential for all students who don't have basic knowledge on statistics.
Jonathan is a special teacher... I think most people really liked the course. But he is enthusiastic and funny. If you want boring and dry, then he's not a good prof for a student.
Talk to the professor and TA(s) outside of lecture!
Don't fall behind!
Take thorough notes, pay attention, always keep up with HW.
Allow more time than you think for both the problem sets and the take home midterms and don't expect to understand everything in the class, especially probability.
It'svery necessary to take this course to write your thesis.
If you need an introductory statistics background, this is the best, most enjoyable class you could take.
Do ALL of the exercises. Pay attention in class even if you don't feel like it.
Start the final project earlier!
You only really learn the stats during homework. It helps to have real research problem or desired outcome that you are actually learning stats to help you solve.
take it
Work hard on the problem sets; really working through the problem sets - though challenging at times - is the best way to learn and understand the material.
Form a study group and make use of it--your peers may be your best help in this class.
Go to class everyday and go to office hours whenever possible.
Prepare to put in the necessary work. Look at the notes before class and again after class. Get help often and frequently.
use spss instead of minitab!

Find a way to identify which chapter in a statistics text book is relevant to the material covered each week and DO THE READING. Also,although I found it hard to do so, it would be very helpful to complete each assignment over the weekend and attend Professor Reuning-Scherer's help sessions that take place before each assignment is due. That way you can verify what you do understand and ask questions about areas that are confusing.
The course is great for students who have never studied stats or who want a refresher. It made me understand data concepts in other classes better, especially regression.
